titlestmt.titleproper: BU Records: Home Economics Department, Inclusive: 1916-1993, undated, Bulk: 1936-77, undated

profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid was generated by The Texas Collection staff, using the STAR Knowledge Center for Archives (SKCA) task that automatically creates EAD files from the Archive's SKCA catalog records.

did.head: Records Summary
did.unittitle: BU Records: Home Economics Department
did.abstract: The Home Economics Department records include correspondence, education materials, literary productions, and photographs relating to Baylor's Home Economics Department.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The history of the Baylor Home Economics Department can be traced back to 1850. Five years after Baylor officially established itself as a university in Independence, Texas, it began teaching home economics classes. In 1933, the Department of Home Economics was established at Baylor in Waco, Texas. At the time, the Department of Home Economics offered three degrees: home economics education, general home economics, and fashion merchandising. The Home Economics Department found its permanent home at the Mary Gibb Jones Home Economics Facility in 1977. In 1994, the department became known as Family and Consumer Sciences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection begins in 1916 and ends in 1993, with a great deal of the collection being undated. The collection includes personal and departmental correspondence between Mrs. T. C. Cardwell, Home Economics teacher in the 1930s, and others. The Education Materials series includes lesson materials, various governmental forms, and notebooks. The Literary Productions series is the largest group of the collection and includes publications on teaching home economics, various recipes, newspaper and magazine clippings, event marketing ephemera, and other publications related to home-making. Most of the collection was compiled by Clyde Newton Cardwell, first chairman of the Home Economics Department.
Some materials in the collection were compiled by previous Texas Collection staff members over time and kept in subject files. These materials were added to the collection during processing.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prior to current processing, this collection was arranged in no particular order in labeled and unlabeled folders. Currently, the collection is arranged in four series: I. Correspondence, II. Education Materials, III. Literary Productions, and IV: Photographs. Within each series, folders are arranged alphabetically. Within each folder, materials were kept in original order, which is not necessarily chronological order.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to The Texas Collection in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: BU Records: Home Economics Department, Accession #BU/107, Box #, Folder #, The Texas Collection, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Leanna Barcelona. Released on 2017-11-28.

did.unittitle: Correspondence

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains correspondence produced by the Home Economics Department, including invitations for events. It also contains correspondence of Mrs. T. C. Cardwell during her time as chairman of the Home Economics Department. Some of the correspondence is personal, but most reference the department in some way. This series is in average to good condition.

did.unittitle: Alumnus Letter
Correspondence: Mrs. T.C. Cardwell
Home Economics Department Event Invitations
Education Materials

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains material related to the education of home economics, including notebooks, lesson materials, and government forms. Most of the material in this series is undated and was collected by Clyde Newton Cardwell. This series is in average condition.

Literary Productions

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This is the largest series in BU Records: Home Economics Department and contains various publications produced by the Home Economics Department, publications related to home economics and vocational education, recipes published by large companies such as Heinz, and clippings collected by students and Clyde Newton Cardwell. It is in average condition.
